{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3723268,"name":"William Babbitt","username":"Wabbitt","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/e480ec/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-25T22:11:00.572Z","cooked":"

I am a programming mentor for a team who is trying to refine their swerve code in the off season. They have ran swerve the last two years, the first year on time-based programming and then last year they switched to command-based. Both times they have written their swerve code from scratch, and although it has worked somewhat, there have been a lot of issues. They are now trying to rewrite last year‚Äôs bot using the WPI kinematics and odometry libraries.

They have this project/branch as a WIP and it seems close to working. As it stands now, the bot is able to translate (left-right, forward-backward) correctly with optimizations. However, when they try to spin the bot the wheels are out of sync.

All four wheels go to a 45 degree, but the front two wheels are spinning backwards. I am confused what could be causing this since we are not doing anything ‚Äúspecial‚Äù for handing translation vs rotation swerve module states and it is functioning during translation. The fact that the wheels go to a 45 properly implies that the joystick feedback is being properly converted to inputs for the modules.

IMG_47831920√ó1089 106 KB

Any advice on how to approach debugging this?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-08-25T22:11:00.572Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":101.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505670,"topic_slug":"swerve-running-half-backwards-when-rotating","display_username":"William Babbitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/Gearhounds/George-2025/tree/Swerve-Rewrite","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - Gearhounds/George-2025 at Swerve-Rewrite","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-running-half-backwards-when-rotating/505670/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3723331,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-25T23:00:57.836Z","cooked":"

For debugging I find AdvantageScope handy. There‚Äôs a module in there that will visualize your desired and measured rotation, speed, and direction for each swerve module. You have to pump the data out to NT to get it to read it, but once you‚Äôve got it figured out I find it quite handy.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-08-25T23:00:57.836Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":42.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505670,"topic_slug":"swerve-running-half-backwards-when-rotating","display_username":"Justin Buist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24678,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-running-half-backwards-when-rotating/505670/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3723589,"name":"","username":"mstatistics","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mstatistics/{size}/267172_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-26T02:08:15.275Z","cooked":"

I agree that using Advantage Scope is likely the next step. Specifically, using this should help you with debugging. I would recommend using the code snippet on that page to see the commanded states and them another copy for the actual states, discovered from the encoders of the modules. If that doesn‚Äôt lead you to a solution, sending a log file or video would be helpful.

I looked at your code in simulation, and all swerve states looks to be applied correctly to me. I might have seen the issue once, but i couldn‚Äôt reproduce it. I did have to mess with the controller a bit for it to work with my setup. Maybe add a deadband? I use a deadband with normal gaming controller joysticks, not sure what you‚Äôre using.

Everything looked correct using your getState() function in the swerve module. I didn‚Äôt have as much time as i would have liked to investigate the logic in each module, but it looked good in the subsystem.

After this bug gets figured out, i would love to share some other tips to improve your codebase

Double-check that you zeroed your absolute encoders with all the wheels in the same orientation (usually bevel-gear to the left). Check that you get positive drive encoder output when you spin the wheels in the forward direction. Then check that you get positive absolute encoder output when rotating the modules left. Check the driving. Possible that you will need to invert your absolute encoder output. Looking at your two versions of the modules, in the New ones you don‚Äôt set any inversions (which is fine), but in the older one you hardcoded the absolute encoder inversions to true. This kind of procedure usually fixes this kind of behavior for me.

@Wabbitt

Double and triple check that the module IDs you have assigned are indeed on the correct physical corners of the robot. This is classic ‚Äúfront left module in code is acually front right on the frame‚Äú (or something similar) behaviour.
